description: The place has been around for as long as I can remember so they must be doing something right. Not the best pizza in San Francisco but hey, variety is the spice of life. I think it is cool they are still there after all these years. =)
author: Andrew W.

description: Tried the Parma pizza extra large. It was very good although it was slightly overcooked. The NY style thin crust should be easy to fold up but this was a little too crispy. But the ingredients were very good and the pizza very tasty.  Service was good not great. All in all this is a nice little neighborhood pizzeria.
author: Sam R.

description:
My favorite pizza place in SF.  Thin-crust, fresh ingredients, VERY down-to-earth vibe, simplest decor.  This place is CLASSIC.

p.s. be sure to check out the framed original menu from 1959.
author: John W.

description: Really the difference between this place and the other pizza places in the sunset is no big screen TV or crazy toppings.  Just a decent cheap pizza option.  I've never been disappointed but that's because I knew what I was getting: a solid cheap pizza that was more than tasty enough.
author: Zack S.

description: Best pizza in the Sunset, and maybe even SF in general! Hard to beat. Good sausage (fresh!), nice thin crust, tasty sauce, and fresh toppings. Every guest we have served it to asks where the pizza is from and can't get enough!
author: Cara K.

description:
My friend ordered Pasquale's for delivery and it was amazing!  

So good that it makes me want to live in this neighborhood!  
Especially, since they just raised my rent! :(
author: Lauren C.

description: We have some Hawaiian friends that's staying with us and they can eat pizza.  They can have pizza every night and won't get tired of it.  We brought them to the 3 neighborhood pizza that we highly recommend... Patxi's Milano's and Pasquale's.  Out of the 3, our friends love Pasquale's.  Pasquale's pizzas were awesome when we had an all meat pizza and a vegeterian pesto sauce pizza.  Both were excellent and our friends are so impressed by the quality of pizza in San Francisco.
author: Kmaintl L.

description: I may have discovered the best pizza in SF! I was pleasantly surprised with the flavor of the sauce on the pizza, and the perfect ratio of sauce: cheese: bread: toppings. The Caesar salad had just the right amount of dressing and it was light, not the heavy, creamy type, which made it even better. They have a good selection of red and white wines by the glass. Our server was very attentive even though the restaurant was jam packed. Nothing fancy about this place; a great family pizzeria with really reasonable prices for everything.
author: Amy J.

description: This is a great old-school Italian food and pizza restaurant. They make the pizza dough by hand, and the ingredients seem to all be freshly prepared. It has a huge dining room that seems great for family gatherings.  And, while I think pizza is something that people all have unique preferences for, personally I find the pizza delicious.
author: Brian M.

description: Coming to this place is the best idea ever. Since one of my friend knew I love to eat pasta,he took me here to try it out. I tried the linguini with fresh calm. It was delicious and they gave me a lot of calms too. I also tried my friend's dish and it was pretty good. I would totally come back again to try more of their dishes. The services was good too. Polite and attentive.
author: Yannie C.

description:
Staff is extremely rude and unpolite.  Honestly, they ruined my evening.

The pizza was alirght.
author: Rodrigo S.

description: Hands down, best pizza in San Francisco and everywhere else I have ever been. My family and I have been going to Pasquale's since as long as I can remember. My grandparents took me when I was small and now I take my children there. We go there after baptisms, for birthdays, farewells, etc. Our family would not enjoy any other pizza place as much as we enjoy Pasquale's with our family.. Hands down, the best pizza in the WoRlD, my WHOLE family would agree!!!!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Tried this place on a whim - we'd seen their delivery guys around our place, so knew they'd make it here.

The plain cheese pizza is as close to what I used to get in NJ as I've had since moving to SF.  Crust is a bit too crunchy, and there's less oregano than when I was a kid.  Good chicken wings.  My wife had sausage, mushrooms, and onions - she liked it a lot as well.
author: Shawna G.

description: This place is delicious! Their pizza is to die for!!!! Pasta is great as well. I've been coming here since I was a kid and you can't beat this place, plus the prices are cheap, too!!!!
author: S. R.

description:
I'm writing this review in regards to their delivery service, and the quality of food as well.

I work in a big building with tons of people hungry come dinner time. In our area, there are limited choices for us if we want to order out come dinner time.  And one of them is Pasquale's Pizza, for our Italian cravings. Guess what? Never again!

We've ordered from them, for, hmmm, seem like forever, maybe 5 plus years now. Recently, they have been fu*&! up big time. I couldn't believe it! How could you mess up an order of 3 CHICKEN Cesar Salads with dressing on the side? Well, Pasquale's sent us 3 orders of STEAK Cesar Salads with dressing already in it!!! I know steak is good too but we are trying to eat healthy ummkay? Bulls&%! We even checked our receipt and they wrote the right order! One one occasion, I ordered the same thing, but instead, they sent a Cesar salad with no CHICKEN in it! Que horror! How am I supposed to last the graveyard shift with just veggies in my tummy?! What's wrong with you people! We've ordered from them for the longest time and they can't get it right? Our building must be the only big business in the area and we operate 24/7, so how can you screw us up especially if we are bringing good business to you???

On the flip side, the hamburgers are pretty good, even though they are ordered for take out. Some dishes like the eggplant parmesan are superb as well. And that's why you get two stars from me, paisanos. Entiende?

All I'm asking is, compromiso! Serve us well and we'll continue to do business. I've not given up hope just yet, because we'd like to support local businesses in our area. So you guys are on our "indefinite suspended list" until you guys right your ship. Cool?
author: Walzyr K.

description:
I had a horrible experience here!
We had called in an order for a ceremony for pick up at 6pm WELL over a week in advance and even called a few days in advance to remind them. When we arrived to pick up the pizzas they were not ready and the order was still not processed. One of the employees proceeded to apologize and got the manager. INSTEAD of just taking responsibility for the mistake, he proceeded to use a fire that was taking place a block away as an excuse as to why he did not complete our order. ummm... NO. We tried to get a discount for our pizzas but he only gave us one pizza on the house (we had ordered 3). We had to wait 20 extra minutes while they made our pizzas and we were late to our ceremony! He had no remorse and he was VERY rude about the situation. 
Honestly, in a situation like this, shouldn't you as the manager try and portray better customer service? You should have comp'd us our pizzas and apologized. Even if you apologized, I would have been ok.

I am livid at the manager and will NEVER return to pasquale's and I will persuade all of my contacts at UCSF NEVER to order pizzas from here again (believe, me I have a GOOD share of student groups that order from here as well) 

I hope the competing pizza joints in the inner sunset area run you down to the ground.

oh, and your pizza is average AT BEST.
author: Tim B.

description:
i came here to pick up a personal pepperoni pizza for my brother one night because we were all having indian and i guess it just wasnt his cup of tea. haha. so we went down the street to the nearest pizza place, which so happened to be pasquale's.

i took a bite just to try it and yea.. it was pretty good, especially for being just pepperoni. i personally anything with mushrooms on my pizzas. =D

pasquale's definitely warrants a second try, so next time im in the neighborhood (and i most definitely will be! esp for HOLY GELATO!) i'll try some sort of mushroom pie.
author: amelia g.

description: One of my favorite pizza places in the sunset! Super tasty, with fresh ingredients. Their italian sausage is the best!
author: Bridget B.

description: Had my fiancées Birthday Party there and it was Amazing!! The pizza was delicious, the service incredible, a great time had by all.  Thank You Pasquale's!!
author: Warren K.

description:
Satisfying and inexpensive pizza. It's not a 'nice' place to go (self-seating and plastic tablecloths) but it's a good place for lunch or delivery.  When I was there there was what appeared to be a kid's birthday party going on in the other room; somehow I got the feeling that a lot of those are held here.  

I saw some other tables order pasta; it looked simple but not amazing.  The pizza itself is on a thin(ner) crust and did not taste heavy. Standard toppings available; you can build your own pizza at pretty good prices.  I intend to come back.
author: K. B.

description: Do not eat here!!!! This is not what pizza is supposed to taste like. I can honestly say this is the worst pizza I have ever eaten, I would rather eat frozen Costo pizza. We have had this pizza a few times, we had it after a few drinks and remember that it was not good, but thought we would try it again while sober...NOPE, still not good!! All the toppings were tossed in the middle of the pizza and it wasn't cooked. And whats with the hand tossed dough out here, doesn't anyone know how to roll a proper pizza. All and all this place was the worst I've ever had, do not eat here...ever..drunk or sober! Now Patxis is where it's at for real pizza!!
author: Nick E.

description:
Here's a little ditty and it goes like this:

Our heroes, four roomies from Noe Valley, were charged with a feat: find delicious, filling Italian food for a decent price. They set out by the light of the full moon, mounted great hills and arrived around 8th and Irving. After vanquishing the parking demons, our heroes took a victory stroll to the towards the glowing lights of Pasquale's. 

Here, folks, is where the adventure turns to romance. As soon as we walked in, a bulky man was talking loudly in Italian. The place was genuine and Mita, The Good Fairy, descended upon us bearing scrolls in a language we understood - Food. Tap water in unbreakable glasses filled the table and hot, sour, par-baked, crusty bread was consumed with a lusty zest (and pats of butter.)

After waving her wand over the magic pad, she vocally proclaimed each of our choices as 'DELICIOUS' - cheese ravioli with pesto, creamy fettucini alfredo, chicken parmagiano sandwich (the BEST!), and Napolean steak sandwich. After Mita validated the heroism of the choices, the heroes settled into the atmosphere: gentle rumble of the good folks, the soft 'pfuff' of pizza dough being thrown into the air, the small child finding delight at hiding under the large, Italian man's table.

Then, the crowning glory - the food was GOOD. Hero-sized portions, hero-sized flavor, lay-people prices. The Heroes were happy and in love with the joint as well as with Mita, the bearer of Laughter and Good Food. 

The heroes returned over the hill and expect to make the trek on a regular basis. And they all lived happily ever after. 

The End
author: Megan S.

description:
P's:      Hello Pasquale's, how can I help you?
Me:       I'd like to order a pizza for delivery
P's:      Okay, what would you like to order.
Me:       A medium cheese pizza.
P's:       Is that all?
Me:       Yes, please.
P's:      Okay, a medium cheese pizza.  Where do you live?
Me:       0000 7th Avenue.
P's:      Cross street?
Me:       Irving St.  Um...yeah...my apartment is actually a block away   from the restaurant.
P's:       Okay...that will be about 30 minutes.
Me:        Thank you.

They get an extra star because they deliver in about 20 minutes a tasty pizza to my lazy couch potato ass. I can get it on my own if I just had the motivation to change out of my too-big-for-me sweats into pants, why bother though?  Why walk one whole block when I can walk ten feet to the door and get my pizza without actually having to exert any real energy.  Thank god I'm not in the cave man days where I'd have to hunt for my food and there aren't any delivery services.  I'd starve and my whole race would die.
author: Jay H.

description:
Yep, it's pizza.  

The Beer and Scripting SIG met here at 8pm, after the dinner rush had dissipated.  We were able to accommodate everyone who walked in, and the pizzas and salads were delivered to the table without a noticeable delay.  

They have a spinach, pesto, garlic, onion pizza that tastes great.  The crusts were an even consistency, not too chewy, not too brittle.  A salad, two pizzas, two pitchers of root beer, and maybe some other things, split among us for about $12 per person.
author: David D.

description:
Some of the best pizza i have had yet! 

On a busy Saturday night i ordered a Pesto pizza with green onions and jalapenos. The pizza was spicy as hell- good thing we were drinking in Yancy's saloon rt next door.

The flavor was so awesome and it was ready for pick up in 15 minutes
author: Andy r.

description:
Here's the deal -- I'm always looking for a good vegetarian pizza. It seems so hard to find from a 'regular' pizza joint. I roll my eyes at the usual "Just take the meat offa the regualr pizza and put on more tomatoes". 

And I have a thing about mushy green peppers. I reminds me of our family's early attempts at making pizza at home with those Kraft Pizza Kits:

Me: Dad, there's no more grated cheese product

Dad: That's ok, son, let the raw dough in the middle be your cheese

At Pasquale's I asked for the Medditerrean special, and it was loaded with pesto (no red sauce), spianch, sliced tomatoes (i'm getting nervous...), garlic and onion. And, of course, a blanket of Mozz.

It's was great -- we'd definitely do it again.

I know I've had a pepperoni slice here before when I was more carnivorous, and it was great too -- thus the return visit....I'm warming up my pizza stone for leftovers as we speak.
author: T C.

description: Been coming here for about 5 years for  dinner with my family the food was great! and awesome service the waitress was very helpful. Recommend the cheese bread!
author: Luis M.

description:
Tonight brought a disappointing close to my nearly 25 years of patronage at Pasquale's. Read on...

I've been coming here since I was a child, a baby even, and lately, I've been coming pretty regularly in the last three years since I moved back to SF. I've hosted a couple birthday dinners here, and tonight I returned with about 15 people to celebrate yet another birthday. It's worked out well in the past, because they make large party dining pretty simple: $12 a person gets you all you can eat pizza, pasta and salad. Good deal, right?

Instead of "all you can eat", we got four pizzas, four dishes of pasta and three salads - barely enough to feed 15 people as you might imagine. We asked for more, and begrudgingly they gave it to us.

The real topper was when we got the bill - they charged us at the rate of 20 people. We complained, and initially got the support of the manager who reprimanded the waiter that overcharged us. Then, in a bizarre and rapid twist of events, he starts calling my friend cheap for complaining, and calls us "thieves" because we utilized the to-go boxes that they provided us with. Naturally this is upsetting, who expects to get treated like this at a restaurant?

My girlfriend tells the manager not to call our friend "cheap" and he gets in her face and starts chewing him out. I step toward him and tell him to "shut the fuck up, don't talk to her like that!" I tell him that I've been coming here all my life, and he asks "So what? What does that matter?" I called him a fucking asshole, and the scene continued like that for another 5 minutes or so. Blah blah, use your imagination.

The manager warns us to never return, and I assured him not to worry. I honestly can't believe it went down like that. Go here if you'd like, but FUCK this place.
author: Alex C.

description:
I enjoyed my "early-dinner" here.  My husband and I shared a medium pizza, baked penne w/ meat sauce and the bruschetto.  Sorry for my spelling errors..  

Pizza was yummy.. penne was yummy, bruschetto was not so yummy.

All in all I would come back.
author: Alice E.

description:
There are pluses and minuses to this pizza but Sure, I'll order from here again depending on what kind of pizza I want.  So what they do well is their cheese.  They use a good amount of cheese and it's actually kinda stringy just the way I like it.  They put a decent amount of toppings too.  

The thing that got me was that there was not enough sauce.  Or if there was, it wasn't too tasty.  I don't like it when some places put too much sauce and it gets messy but I feel like a really good pizza place puts just the right amount and they just didn't do it for me.  

Maybe I'll try ordering extra sauce next time and see where that takes me....
author: Mark W.

description: great crust, great people.  I go here for low key pizza/italian food.
author: p w.

description:
I've never eaten in this restaurant, but rely on them regularly for delivery. They have a large assortment of dishes- pizzas included.

The pizzas produce lukewarm feelings for me. Once you've eaten pizza at A16 or Delfina, is there really anything that can compare? For a delivered pizza, I guess it's okay.

The real attraction to this place are it's sandwhiches- veal parmigian, meatball, etc. Every sandwhich I've had is huge, served on hearty halves of French sourdough bread. Each sandwhich comes with a small salad.

The homemade soup is decent- more appropriate on a cold or rainy day with it's thick consistency.

The baked tortellini is generous enough for two people and offers another comfort food item for less-than-desirable days.
author: Ben R.

description:
I truly believe the cure for your damaged liver after puking up some nasty bile is a Pasquale's pizza w/ extra cheese and sausage. well psychologically, yes. but physically, I don't really know.

try their amazing linguine & clams with the white sauce -- spectacular ! maybe it's my tongue but this Pasquale's pizza sauce tastes a bit more sour than the Pasquale's by the zoo. tastes just fine though, doesn't stop me from gorging and enjoying
author: Prima D.

description:
Thank you to Don and everyone at Pasquale's for providing the FANTASTIC pizza to all of us drunk Yelpers at the Bay 2 Breakers afterparty at Yancy's! That pizza was the closest thing to NY pizza that I have had since I moved to Cali. I know exactly where to get my pizza from now on! 

And the prices are cheaper than the other pizza places in the neighborhood. Can't go wrong with Pasquale's!
author: Jen D.

description: $5 personal pizza. Daaaamn this place is so popular they ran out of dough!
author: Christopher R.

description:
Yuck :(.

My friend and I were exploring her new neighborhood a few weeks ago and stopped in here for lunch. We thought it was the restuarant her mom had mentioned was her favorite pizza place while growing up. So we really wanted to check it out. 

I think we got the wrong place.

I think the waiter was on crack or something. He was really out of it and sweaty and his eyes were bouncing around in his head. Do what you gotta do dude, but mmmmaaaaaaayyyybe not when your serving people their food. I don't know, maybe I'm old fashioned...

We ordered a spinach and feta pizza. Good in theory, nasty in excecution.The cheese was rubbery, the crust was thin and stale. Fresh spinach is delicious. This was NOT fresh spinach. I think its the kind you get out of the can (the kind that used to make me quake in fear when I was a kid). It was so gross. We barely ate our slices, which is unheard of!

Nice try Pasquale's.
author: Ashley R.

description:
No complaints whatsoever. I believe Pasquales has the best pizza in the city. Easy to get to, easy to get home from. Fresh ingredients were noted. 

Give it a try, I don't think you'll be disappointed.
author: Wayne B.

description:
Damn i really wanted to like this place too...

The first time i drove by and saw the old 'Pasquale' sign on the corner of 9th and Irving, i instantly had a one of those "This has to be some authentic Italian pizza" feelings. I vowed i would love this place no matter what it tasted like.

So filled with high expectations, i tried it. Hmph.

The sauce is pretty good, the pepperonis are sliced pretty thin, the crust ends up a little hard-- it ain't that bad of a pie, but at the same time it really isn't all that special. 

The staff here seems pretty friendly, and the menu looks pretty big. I'm sure I'll come back here again to try another pizza, or maybe some veal-- but for right now it's just A-OK
author: Greg G.

description: Went here for a take out pizza after a night of football. They were really nice and allowed us to buy a few beers and have a seat at a table while we waited for our pie. Price was right, food was tasty and exactly what we expected. It was a lovely night time snack and we will be back!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Having patronized this place for over 5 years, I'm finally done.  Recently, their drivers are so dumb they've failed to deliver my food twice in a row!  Both times, they've had BS excuses like my phone didn't work, and they actually coped an attitude when I refused to tip them when it took two attempts to get my food.

Life is too short to pay inept people to make you wait.
author: Otto D.

description:
+Pasquale's Seafood Special

Did you notice this place in that dog commercial for that insurance company?
author: JC R.

description:
While their pizza is decent, I'm really disappointed in their customer service.

When I order pizza, whether it be for personal or business reasons, and I ask for delivery, I expect it to be delivered to me.  I don't walk around the corner of my house and pick up the pizza, and I shouldn't have to meet the delivery driver outside of my work because "it's busy" in the park.

I work at the Academy of Sciences, and it being the week after Christmas, it's packed.  I had to argue with the person on the phone to get them to deliver to our reception desk, they refuse because it's so busy.  We give them a lot of business, and to be honest, I don't want to order from them again because of how I was treated on the phone.  

Maybe they need to rethink their "delivery" policies!
author: Rachael J.

description: Crust tasted like cheap bread sticks.  Tomato sauce tasted like it had been left out or something.  They charged us for four toppings when we got two different toppings on each half of the pizza, so each half only had two toppings on it.  We were about to bring this up with the waitress who just gave us "meh" service to begin with, but she saw us talking about it and came over and told us that the policy of the place dictates we should be charged for four toppings for this horrible pizza.  The only reason my friends and I even finished the pizza was because we were so hungry from playing tennis and my friend had the brilliant idea to smother the pizza with Parmesan.  In addition I added pepper on top of my slice, the first time I've ever attempted that in my life.  P.S.  Why the hell do they have a black light over the painting on the wall?
author: eli l.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a little kid. The pizza is great, a nice chewy crusty crust. love the antipasti. everyone is friendly.
~J
author: Jamie S.

description: I have enjoyed their pizzas for a couple of years now.  Nothing fancy, but just good stick-to-your-bones pizza.  Writing this review is making me hungry...
author: Joe L.

description:
My family has been eating Pasquale's Pizza since before I can remember.

There is something so homey and familiar about the atmosphere and menu-a feeling I bet would be applicable even if it was your first visit.

Every pasta dish I've had here has been great, and their pizzas are always a pleaser.  But let's face it-the cheap beer at this place *totally* helps with their spot in our regular restaurant rotation.

Service is almost always attentive and friendly, although in an informal family run type of restaurant way.

Basically, this place is a great staple to the neighborhood for some very hearty cheap eats!

*tip* the half order of pasta is the same size as a regular order at most restaurants-so only order a full if you're REALLY hungry or want leftovers!
author: Monica B.

description:
Pasquale's pizza is really some of the best pizza in San Francisco.  The trick is to get it fresh so I do not recommend having it delivered, either eat there or pick it up yourself.  

Joe , the manager,  is one of the nicest people you will ever meet and he greets you with true Italian hospitality...now were do you find that now a days?
author: G L.

description:
I sometimes come here with a couple of friends after working out. I have to agree with many of the yelpers that the pizza here is amazing. It's best if you dine in. The staff are really friendly. This was also the first place I discovered artichoke is a delicious topping to have on your pizza. Whenever we go, we each choose a topping (a large pizza can generously feed 4 people for a very reasonable price). I'm a big mushroom fan! Our usual combination consist of artichokes, sausage, pepperoni, and mushroom.

The servers make sure your water is constantly filled. The noise level is peaceful. Parking can be challenging (Irving st.)  but around 9pm, it's not bad at all.

I love this place.

Final Thoughts: mmmm....artichokes
author: Jason N.

description:
The food here is solid, I would prefer this place over Giorgios any day though.

Big portions, pizza was delicious, pasta was also delicious and they could lay off the garlic on the bruschetta but that was also quite good.

Service was quick and polite. Nothing more to say about this place really. Just keep in mind you wont be hungry when you leave~
author: phillip w.

description:
I give this place a 3 Stars because they make good pizzas. Whether you are ordering off the menu or creating your own topping choices, you can never go wrong. They can also make the pizza dough extra thin like the Neapolitan style or even extra crispy by request. I usually like my pizza thin and crispy. 

The restaurant is very family style oriented like an Italian trattoria. It is a place where locals living in the neighborhood go and a place where everybody working at the restaurant knows your name. The wait staff have been working there forever so the services you get is consistent. The most exciting part of the restaurant has to be the long pizza counter by the window where you can watch the chefs toss pizza dough in the air and construct the pizzas from scratch. 

The pasta on the other hand is not impressive. Almost every time I order a pasta dish the pasta are over cooked and never al dente. Also in my opinion, they are a little generous with the sauce or should I say too generous because the pasta is always swimming in the sea of marinara or white cream sauce. However their lasagna is very hearty and baked to perfection with a healthy portion enough for two. 

Other dishes like veal Milanese, egg plants Parmesan, veal piccata are well made, home-style cooking and simple recipes that are worth trying. 

No doubt I am not thrill with their pasta, but I like going to Pasquale mainly because I've been going there for years now, the staff are friendly and services are good every time. Pasquale is not a fancy, 5-Star Michelin's restaurant, but it is a comfortable, casual local hang out with good Italian food.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
I feel so bad, writing bad things about the place, especially since other people seem to like it:  like, my fiance, my best friend and her out of town guest.  Maybe it's just me.  Since I wasn't a fan but everyone else I was dining with that night is, I'm going to write my thoughts and then give their points of view too, so that you get an opinion from both sides of the spectrum.  

Classic neighborhood Italian place: green, red and white color scheme, older tables and decor, large counter for you to watch them make the dough, and young waiters.  Lots of pasta, pizza, salad and appetizer options.  Menus were kinda dirty though.  Maybe it's time to get some new menus.  

They offered garlic cheese pesto bread which my other half promptly ordered even though our out of towner was discussing lactose intolerance issues as he ordered.  That was okay, but I felt the bread was a bit soggy.  My fiance, liked it, and ate more than one serving, but yet he didn't finish the whole order.  The out of towner was laying off carbs I think, and the best friend, she ate mini slice.

We also got the baked ravioli which didn't knock my socks off but the best friend seemed to love it, as did the fiance- I felt it was just a bunch of pasta stuffed with cheese and covered in cheese and red sauce.  I think maybe I'm just not a red sauce fan.  

And of course, we also got two pizzas that I didn't like because it was so heavy that the toppings and cheese fell off when you picked it off- you had to eat it with a fork and knife.  Me- I like super thin crust pizza that when you lift it up and fold it in half to put in your mouth, nothing falls off............... This one was too full of stuff ( that to me didn't taste all that great) and the crust was too think.  Again my best friend and fiance, and the out of towner liked it.  

So, maybe it's me that is the problem.  Maybe it's them, and they don't know good food.  Either way, I probably will be back, since everyone else loves it.  And maybe then I'll just have to try someone thing else until something sticks with me as something I like.  Or maybe I just like a more modern Italian place.  Who knows?/
author: Denise B.

description:
Classic family italian/pizza place.  Everything you could expect from the midwest pizza parlor without the actual quality pizza.  Don't get me wrong, it was all right...for west coast pizza.

Over-run by kids.  Wait staff was very nice, but there definitely were not enough when we were there.  They were getting SLAMMED!

I would go back sometime as there doesn't seem to be too much of a wait even on a Saturday night.
author: Chris M.

description:
"Meh"  Though it would beat out majority of chains (like grease-infused Pizza Hut or sauce-overload Papa Johns) it was nothing particularly impressive.  We got some pesto pepperoni pizza and though it was tasty enough to appease us at the time, I've definitely had better slices in my life.

The guys were really cool and they have a super old school cash register which was probably the coolest thing about the place.  We were able to walk to it, which was nice, and didn't have to wait for too long for the finished pie.  But next time when I get a pizza craving, I'll probably just get it delivered from one of the other hundreds of pizza established freckling SF...I'm sure there's something better out there.
author: Robin L.

description:
Seemed like it was trying hard to be a traditional pizza joint and comes off more like cheap diner meets Italian.

I really didn't think much of the food at all. The pizza repeated on me for hours and it really didn't taste that great the first time, and the nausea... It just didn't agree with me.

It seemed overpriced for what they offered overall I wouldn't go back.
author: Marz W.

description: You won't be let down! It may not be mind blowing, but Pasquale's is consistently good. Cheap beers and large servings of both pasta and pizza.
author: Clutch R.

description:
What's more depressing than eating here on Valentine's Day with your (male) roommates? 

Probably the fact that we all ordered ribeye steaks. At Pasquales. Pasquales Pizza. 

That was our bad i guess, but did that waiter with the one gericurl down his forehead have to be so cold? The dude stood in silence as we ordered, asked for more water, and paid the bill. Who is he, Anne Frank? SAY SOMETHING GUY
author: Steven H.

description: Me and friend got two personal pepperoni, chese and mushrooms pizza. The crust what nice and crunchy on the edges. I like mostly the sauce used, tasted good olive oil and fresh tomatoe sauce. Toppings were great.
author: Dee B.

description:
"Well I like it here.  This is a good place with some real SF flavor -- not a trendy overpriced north beach place that can't even do simple spaghetti marinara well.  I am not fond of their pizza; you can definitely find better elsewhere (Polk st. & Kearney St. both have better spots for pie), but I adore their baked ravioli.  For less than $10 you actually get a family sized platter.  I've been to places where you get appetizer like proportions for nearly twice that price.

I also found the shrimp salad to be amply sized and pretty tasty.  Is it the best italian food on earth? God no, but it's tasty, filling, affordable for the city, and very relaxed atmosphere without being filthy."
author: Eric X.

description:
I was pretty disappointed by this place... the pizza just plain wasn't very good. It wasn't bad, I mean, it was still pizza, but really not that good. It was pretty greasy (expected), and the crust was pretty tough and not that tasty.

They were really nice though, and seemed to know their way around a pizza. I had them make me a pesto and pepperoni, which is a magical combination of delicious, and pretty hard to screw up. Their pesto was OK, and I mean pepperoni is pepperoni, but the crust really killed it.

With all the other (better) pizza options out there, I doubt I'll be back!
author: Ben Y.

description:
My fiance turned me on to Pasquale's when I moved to the city.  He grew up going there for pizza and apparently they have not changed much in 30 years.

I love the pizza and the antipasto salad!  It certainly is better to go in an eat.....but the delivery is OK.  The have messed up the delivery a couple of times...but not to bad.  It usually comes luke-warm so we have to heat it up.

BUT, its always great when we go in.....and the biggest, pickiest critic of all-my Italian mother-likes the place.  So now we have somewhere to bring her when she comes into town!

We don't order pizza from anywhere else usually!
author: Claudia M.

description:
I have waited over 3 years to write this review.  Well not really.  I just noticed I hadn't reviewed it yet.  Which is odd.  So I must have been waiting.  Yes, that's it.  I was waiting.

I have casually ended up at this place, or ordering from it, at least 6 times in the last 3 years.  Each time it was different:

Out of desperation with a random group of people that don't know what they want, and Pasquale's incredibly late night (for the inner sunset) menu.  These guys deliver a huge range of well sealed, transported Italian food that is delivered hot, well prepared and DELICIOUS.  I know the latter is incredibly important compared to the others, but it all comes together so well you might as well be at the restaurant.

Drunk, with my ladyfriend, desperate for food on the way home from a gig or some concert.  Their pizza by the slice is exceptional.

My neighbour and I having a boys night of horror films and delicious ... pizza.  Couldn't agree on anything and we ended up ordering pizza from here.

Ordering sandwiches delivered... where I asked them to keep the meatballs and bread separate so I could do it myself, and when it arrived and I combined all the ingredients... I think I had the best meatball marinara sub I have ever had.

It is never a place I would have ordered from on my own.  But all these different experiences being solid... delicious food reasonably priced.  So close, totally reliable, great staff..... authentic and delicious...  I have to admit I think of this place anytime my stomach rumbles and I am home thinking of delivery.



  And here we go....
... I think one of the best pizzas in the city.

(If not the best)
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I really really cannot believe all the good reviews for this place. Maybe their pizza is actually good? I wouldn't know.

The boyfriend and I came here one evening, and we were absolutely starving. Normally, food tastes better when you're hungry. Not this place.

I'm a big lasagna fan. Not a lot of places have it. This restaurant has a really impressive-looking menu, which made me assume they knew how to cook all kinds of stuff. How unfortunate.

He ordered the linguine with white clam sauce, which he'd never had before, but my mom used to make it all the time. It should be awesome. Now, it wasn't BAD here...it was just completely unremarkable. It was underspiced and underflavored and blah.

What can I even say about my lasagna? Okay, well. When they say it's meat lasagna, they're understating it. They should just call it meat. Period. Now, I like meat. A lot. But this was ridiculous and frankly rather disgusting. Here's what I was served: A ten-inch square of compacted oddly-spiced sausage, with one lasagna noodle wrapped around the outside corners and a little bit of sauce and cheese scattered across the top.

How did this happen? Normally my problem with lasagna is it has too MANY noodles and not enough filling. Can it even properly be called lasagna when less than 10% of it is lasagna noodles?

I thought this place looked like a bargain until I ate there. Afterward all I could do was wish I could leave without paying. This is the worst food I've had in a San Francisco restaurant EVER.

Also: Did I mention they gave us MARGARINE spread for our dinner rolls?
author: Lynae Z.

description: Excellent pizza. Extremely hospitable service.
author: S M.

description:
This is one of those places where I've always wanted to try it everytime I've walked by, but never had the chance to. Until yesterday. Blame it on pms, blame it on my current motto of "diet shmiet carbs shmarbs" but I had a monster sized craving for some italian and decided to wander over to Pasquale's. I must say nothing has ever satiated a craving as well. The portions are huge. One order of pasta could feed a small country in Africa (which means i had an appetite the size of half that... holy...). I had the seafood linguine with the red sauce - amazing. The boy had veal parmigana. Ok that wasn't THAT good, but heheh it wasn't my entree. From what I observed at other tables, the pizza looked scrumptious. It looked like one of those situations where if no one was looking, you'd steal a slice off their table after they'd left. Not to say I've ever done that. I'm just saying...

The big plus - the waitress was super nice and friendly, which, for a pms-y girl, is a godsend. She came over and checked on us frequently, and poked fun at me for not eating the tenticles of the squid. The best part? She put the rest of our wine in a to-go cup!! Wine in a to-go cup. Come on!!
author: Karva S.

description:
Abbastanza buono.  Hearty straightforward old school Italian American food. Sizable entree portions sans sizable prices, lots of choices on the menu.

Go light on that garlic bread or you'll be seeing aless amore.
author: GIR ..

description:
I adore their bruschetta to go.  SO YUM.

Last time though, the bread was a boat carrying very, very, very few bruschetta-bit passengers.  

We gave it one more try today and were disappointed to find the passengers to be few once again.

What the eff guys?  Seriously.  There used to be so much.  

We're super sad because bruschetta and white wine was a nice dinner for us on occasion.  Boo Hoo.

===update===
Had a hankering for this dinner to-go.  I specifically asked for a little more of the 'topping.'  Opened the container whenI got home and could hardly see any bread!  YUM.

===update again===
Just tell them not to skimp on the topping & we're good.  Back up to 4 stars again.
author: Megan G.

description:
Great pizza, always space, good luck with parking.

Whenever we have a big group, there are NO worries here. They easily accommodate a bunch of groups at the same time.

Good tasting pizza, good thin crusts, really friendly staff, good for late night dinner and decent prices.

Parking is the only pull back.
author: Angel L.

description:
My family and I have been eating here for over 40 years now and it has always been the favorite pizza place for all of us our entire lives! Since we were children our favorite "me, my brother and my sister, even our parents" has been salami and mushroom; sometimes with olives and sometimes without. I have tried many pizza places in San Francisco over the years and some of them are good or even better than Pasquale,s but this is and has always been our go to pizza place! Maybe it is because we grew up on it and its like comfort food to us, but I we never get tired of it and it remains as our favorite pizza place anywhere! I also love the minestrone soup and bread as well! It's hard to believe but I have never tried their pasta or anything else they serve here, but that's because whenever we are here it's for pizza! I do have some critiques though! When we order a sausage pizza the sausage is always way too salty and ruins the whole pizza from the over powering saltiness! And the place on Irving at least has really gone way down hill since the good ol days; particularly over the past few years. Not only me, but my brother have both noticed that sometimes we'll order a salami and mushroom pizza and it taste just bad! The pizza does not have enough sauce, the crust is burnt on the bottom, it seams like they are skimping on the cheese and the mushrooms even taste different! And it just tastes salty! It seams like they hired some new cooks who don,t know how to make them right! If my review were based on the few times I've eaten here when I got these bad pizzas, I would be leaving a one or two star review, but I am basing my review on 40 years of mostly good pizza! I mean come on! leave Pasquale's a bad review? It's 
Pasquale's ;-)
author: David A.

description:
I like this place.  It's not great Italian.  The pasta is a bit on the flavorless side, but the portions are generous and with a little red pepper flakes and some salt, it's not bad.  The service was good as was the pizza.

In a sense, the vibe is definitely that of a pizzeria, and I mean that as a compliment.  If the place had some video games, it would've been like a mom & pop Shakey's.  (Are there any Shakey's left?")  Even if there are, Pasquale's is a good place for that grown up Shakey's lover who wants the food, the family feel without the loud kiddies yelling at bleeping screens.
author: g. m.

description: I work at UCSF and not only do order frequently from Pasquale's, so do a lot of my friends.  Last night I ordered two nights worth of food.  When I opened my order for tonight's dinner, I had been given shrimp (that stinks), instead of the steak salad, I had ordered.  I called them tonight.  I even said I would order some more wings if they would make good on my salad.  I was told that there was nothing they could do tonight, and to call at 3 tomorrow afternoon.  I explained, I am hungry now, and I would be 50 miles away, home and in bed at that time, and again was told to call at 3 tomorrow afternoon.  Suffice it to say, I won't ever be calling them again.
author: Theresa L.

description:
I have 3 pre-requisites:

1.A regular pie should NEVER be over $20--think about it, how much does flour, water, sauce, cheese, and 1 probably underpaid kitchen worker cost?  Not $20.

2.There should be some grease. No fat cheese is not cheese, it's crap. Cheese should never have the consistency of plastic.

3.The crust should be even just a little crispy.

This place meets all the pre-req's.   There's nothing worse than paying more than $20 for a crappy pie.
author: alex t.

description:
This is the "Mr. Cellophane"  of pizza restaurants.  After living in the InSet (I'm trying to inject my own jargon in here) for over a year, I had still not eaten here.  I had walked by it probably a good 300 times.  And several of those times I was probably hungry.  But I still never walked in. 

I don't know why.  Maybe it's all the options that surround it.  Maybe it's because I was trying to avoid eating a lot of carbs (Yeah right.  Half the time I end up at Carbs and Curry down the street).  I almost went once in the fall.  

Then last week I got home kinda late.  Now pretty much everything in the area closes at 10:00 pm.  But you know what doesn't?  That's right!  Pasquale's Pizza.  I don't know how late they're open, but it's later than 10, and that's exactly what I needed.  

I got a small tomato cheese and artichoke heart pizza to go.  The crust strikes a happy medium: crisp, but foldable; thin, but more too it than "thin crust."  Really fresh ingredients and just enough cheese without going overboard.  

This place has gone from "unnoticed" to pleasantly "unassuming" in my book, and kind of reminds me of the sort of mom and pop place I used to have my birthday parties at as a kid in my hometown that was too small for chains.
author: James M.

description:
On a un-seasonally hot Winter day, this is a great place to get some pizza. It's pretty light tasting, there's no air conditioning, but who needs it! The meats are not that greasy and the decoration is neat. The only knock is that if you choose to split the toppings doing a half and half, they charge you for each item individually. That really sucks in my mind. Otherwise, it's a pretty neat place to go. 

Check it out!
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I honestly think this place deserves zero stars. My boyfriend  and I came in on a sunday night around 7:30pm, and ordered a medium pizza and caeser salad. Upon walking in we were greeted by the owner who just yelled a careless hello, as if he could barely care. We waited to be seated by a server, and everyhting was fine until the plates arrived. The plates we were given were dirty and mine had a large speck of dried food stuck on it. We tried to get one of the waiters` attention, but they looked directly at us and ignored us. When we finally got our waitresses attention I politely told her that my plate was dirty, and she rudely took it back without even apologizing for the dirty plate. The next plate I got also had a dirty dried up speck of food on it....come on!!!!!! I didnt have any patience waiting for a new plate and got up and asked for a new plate myself. The waitress told me that they are just scratches and the plates are not dirty. I showed her the dried up food speck on the plate, and she started arguing with me they are scratches. First of all you shouldnt argue with a customer, second of all I wasnt talking about the scratches on the plate. How can they be scratches when it comes right off when you scrape it off? Use your brain lady. She should of apologized from the very first plate that was dirty, much less argue with a customer. 

The pizza we had was disgusting. I ordered thin crust and it was completely soggy. It was like someone had soaked it in water for 30 minutes. I waited for the pizza to cool down, but even after it cooled down everything was falling off the pizza. The crust was nowhere near crispy as thin crust has to be (except the very end of the pizza). I have had much better pizza before. You can tell this pizza was not made with love.

disgusting food, non-existent service, hell no I am not returning to this place, and I will make sure to tell everyone I know about how crappy their service and food is. Their portions are huge but you sacrifice quality for quantity.
author: Emily G.

description:
I've been getting pizza from Pasquale's for about ten years and I haven't ever come out of there still hungry or unsatisfied.  I don't know why many of the complaints have been about their service or the people working there because I always seem to be greeted on the way in by the pizza chefs and never left standing there for very long before a server greets me.  Eat in or delivery, it's both damn good pizza.

I had pasta there recently and that didn't disappoint either!  I just went there last night for the 2nd time in a week.
author: Chris C.

description:
Two words that will change your life:

PESTO BREAD 

It will suck you into its own vortex.  I can't come here without having some.  Never had the pizza, but it always smells really good.  Love the pasta here, and they give you SO MUCH.  I am a food machine and I always only eat half of my meal.  Their salads are also huge.  They have also very quickly delivered awesome pesto gnocchi to my lazy ass in the Panhandle.
author: jess l.

description:
I used to come here a lot b/c my mom used to work at the BofA a block away, so I remember their pizza being worth it. Our little family of 4 hung out in the city today and I was actually hoping to devour some dry fried chicken wings down the street, but we were starving and upon passing San Tung and witnessing the crowd waiting for tables outside, it got vetoed. Drove up Irving and scored a spot in front of the post office, metered unfortunately. So that only gave us an hour. 

We're boring when it comes to pizza. Sausage and mushrooms. And we also ordered a side of fries, b/c I wasn't sure if the lilmiss would dig pizza this time around. The fries were of the steak variety. Yum, my favorite. Came out nice and hot and soon our pizza followed. I loooooooooooove the crisp crust of their pizza. Just the right amount of toppings too. We all shared a medium and it was more than enough. The fries... there weren't any left.

We normally don't eat in when it comes to pizza, we're delivery or pick up kinda people and we enjoy eating in the comfort of our own home. But Pasquale's was definitely a nice change in our usual pizza routine. And thankfully the weather was nice in the city today too.
author: Dina V.

description:
Serviceable* pizza--that's probably the most accurate way I can describe it.  Serviceable pizza served by an awfully polite staff in an atmosphere that I kind of like, even though I like neither college kids nor children. (Can't quite explain that one. I don't know, is it like vestigial? Redolent of happy birthday parties at Chuck E. Cheese's? Something like that.)

If you really want to get your pizza fix in this neighborhood and have an oven, pick up a pizza from Arizmendi and bring it home. If you feel up to a (very) small wander, then head to Club Deluxe on Haight. And if you're feeling really ambitious then, well...you're in San Francisco; the sky's the limit. No need to hang out on a very small hill.



*By "serviceable pizza" I mean: crust that is not at all crispy but is instead doughy and moist and chewy; and tomato sauce that has very little in the way of herbs, zings, or other elements that might make you pause and say to yourself, Now *that's* interesting. To be honest, so much else is negotiable, but not these two things.
author: T U.

description:
I have had Pasquele's Pizza on two different occasions and had two different experiences. The first time I ate at the restaurant and the pizza was good, but not fantastic. The restaurant itself is not impressive and we walked past the place twice before we realized it was pizza place and walked in; It's a little old an dingy and lacks character. It also took a really really long time for us to receive our pizza. 

The second time I ate at Pasquale's Pizza was a night I went to Yancy's, which is just a few steps away. We ordered pizza, picked it up and enjoyed it with our beer. This time I really enjoyed the pizza and thought it was fantastic. I don't know if it was the beer, the atmosphere or the actual pizza but I that night at Yancy's I thought I was eating pizza from a completely different Place. 

So if I had to rate Pasquale's based on my first dining experience there I would have definitely given them two stars. Although the pizza was good the service and place was not. 

But if I had to rate Pasquale's based on the pizza I had the night I went to Yancy's I would have given them four stars. So, overall based on my two very different experiences with Pasquale's Pizza, I will give them a whopping three stars. 

Try it out..preferably at Yancy's or another bar down the street.
author: Denise S.

description:
This place is perfect for a casual pizza place you can just stop in and get a  hot and delicious pizza pie fesh out of the oven.  Its thin, crispy and slightly greasy, in a good way of course. I always order the cheese pie and believe it to be the test between real pizza and cheese thrown on top of bread. But if you must mess with perfection, the homemade sausage make a delicious topping. 
I also tried the meatballs recently and they were damn good. Usually I only eat homemade meatballs (shout out to J. La's balls!) but these were tasty. And they came covered in meat sauce- cha ching!
author: Jane K.

description: I loved this pizza when I lived here 10 years ago, and out of nostalgia - we ordered for delivery: Xtra large with spinach, sausage, eggplant, garlic and mushroom.....All my favorite toppings! And, can't get it this way anywhere else...Other pizza joints will question you like you are crazy.
author: M. M.

description: An old fashioned family owned pizza joint, the service is friendly and efficient, the prices fair, and while I didn't get a salad they looked to be good-sized. The pizza itself is perfectly ok, but not great. A good choice if you happen to be in the area.
author: Tom B.

description: Food is always good here. The menu is a beast so it's always hard to pick just one thing. Over the weekend I had the spaghetti alla carbonara...off the hook. The smell of the pancetta was enticing and the cream sauce was no lightweight. Even though it doesn't look intimidating, It's an overwhelming dish so bring your appetite. The sourdough was fresh, soft and hot. Couldn't really complain about anything though I wish they'd get rid of the uncomfortable, old school metal chairs.
author: O'Shea J.

description:
We've been coming to Pasquale's for over 12 years and we always get the garlic and cheese pizza. It is heavenly! The crust is thin and crispy, yet substantial, the garlic is minced and drizzled over the pizza with oil (the oil keeps the garlic tasting fresh and soft, not dry or bitter) and the marinara sauce is really flavorful, as it should be in traditional pizzas. Granted, it can be a little oily as with any pizza, but I figure with the garlic, it's good HDL cholesterol, and you can dab it with a napkin if you want to absorb the excess oil. 

We've since moved to other parts of the state, but I've never forgotten the garlic pizza at Pasquale's. On a recent visit back to the City, I was really excited to see Pasquale's is still here, and I promptly ordered... you guessed it: garlic and cheese pizza.
author: Aegean D.

description: Service was slow. Pizza tasted odd.
author: Tiffany S.

description: The food is so-so, but the staff is friendly and the prices are dirt cheap.  If you order any of the pasta dishes, you'll need to load up on parmasean cheese to add flavor.  The bread is decent, but nothing to rave about and the salad is comparable to any fast food restaurant.  The pizza is probably the best thing I've had on the menu and is a step up from Escape from New York and other local pizza joints.  You get what you pay for, plus good service.
author: Sarah K.

description:
You know, I have always like Pasquales. I have never dined in, which I have always been told really reduced the overall experience of a decent pizza from them. We always get delivery. Usually when I call I get put on hold. No biggie, right?

So tonight I call for a pizza.... I am exhausted, I have worked 30 hours in the last two days. 

"pasquales can you hold?"

Sure no problem.... So I am holding.... and holding... maybe 6 to 8 minutes. No biggie, right? So then he picks back up.....
"Anyways, like I was saying.... hello??"

"Um, I would like to place an order for delivery?" 

To which he replies, "Wait, I hit the wrong button"

Goes back to his call. I sit there on hold for ten more minutes. Nothing. Nada. Screw this.

Sorry Paquales, you have now permanently lost my business. Escape from NY delivers just as quickly. I like to support the neighborhood businesses, but seriously. Ridiculous.

I am too cross eyed with exhaustion to spell check, but not to tired to Yelp, apparently.
author: Kellyanne i.

description: When I move to the neighborhood my bff got excited because now she had a good excuse for stopping at Pasquale's, her favorite pizza place.  Now, I grew up on Chicago pizza, then lived in NYC for many years so I know pizza pretty well.  When my bff and I went to P's, I was a little disappointed with the pizza but chalked it up to theh fact I was used to Chicago deep dish and NYC-style pizza.  I've had pizzas from here periodically over the years but do not find it any better (or worse) then any other pizza you can get from Cybelle's or Milano's or Romano's or, now, Patxi's.  The crust seems a little less "soggy" then the other places (my friend loves to take that edge crust and butter it up and eat it separately).  Have never had anything else but the pizza.  And like all these pizza place, when you order an achovy pizza they hardly give you any anchovies--and I've ordered a pizza with double the anchovies and you still get very few.  But, I like my pizzas-in-California a little more cooked (so the stuff on top gets just a little browned and crispy) so I always shove the pizzas into the oven to cook for 10-15 mins longer after we get them delivered, and on the anchovy pizzas I just put a couple more cans of fish on there.  Pasquale's is just fine, nothing extraordinary but it's edible and is about as good as anywhere else in this town.
author: Kai T.

description:
loved this place until i  walked in on the lady at the front picking her nose when i came to pick up my pizza order..nuff said.

i cant eat there with out the image in the back of my mind.totally ruined the good pizza for me.

besides that, i think there pizza is great
author: Rebecca T.

description: the manager is rude!!!!  They mess up our order all the time and the manager hung up on me when I asked to make it right
author: Jordyn S.

description: mediocre at best.  Here is a suggestion. You are in San Francisco. Italian Food , what about serving your customer some great Sour Dough bread to go with your food.  That soft bread is really for the birds.
author: brian l.

description:
WARNING: THEY CHARGE FOR RE-FILLS OF SODA???

Pasquale's is very popular among my main-core of friends. The food is good. But, like many Italian restaurants the entrees seem expensive for what you get.

The Pizza is good.

The sandwiches are a bargain! Generous portions (I usually take half home and I'm a big eater) and they come with potatoes or salad.
author: BigJohnS F.

description:
This was yummy! Nothing fancy, but some good tasting, filling food. 

We came here with a group of about 30 late one evening, after my friend passed his black belt exam in jujitsu. We were about 30 minutes late for our reservation, and they totally accommodated us. I got the calamari steak milanesa, and it was excellent - I'd never had calamari like that before. The food came so quickly you have to wonder how they cooked it... but all in all, I was impressed how well they handled our big group, and the quality of the food.

Only complaint was that the waitress made a big deal about splitting our checks - but she let us calculate our own gratuity, so props to her for that. We tipped well, even if she wouldn't split the check.
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
Someone call the COPS, because I've been ROBBED!

I hereby endeavor to perform a public service by proclaiming that any review herein of Pasquale's above 2 stars is the product of mass hypnosis conducted at Pasquale's bequest.

Or at least that's the only explanation I can come up with for the absurdly high ratings that Yelpers have given this place.

So it started like this:  I was craving pizza and caesar salad, so I combed through Yelp looking for the right spot.  I decided to make a Sunday pilgrimmage to Pasquale's based on the ratings herein.

I had to abandon my pizza + caesar combo plan when I discovered it would cost me over $20 (not counting tax and tip!), so I went with caesar ($6) and meatball sandwich ($6.25) instead.  The waitress warned me that the salad was large, but this was music to my ears.  The meal started off fine, with sourdough bread & butter to go along with my salad.

Now, I fancy myself as a bit of a ceasar salad officianado.  I've tried the caesar salad at probably close to 100 restaurants (if not more) in Oregon, California, Arizona and Hawaii.  You could say that I'm on a perpetual quest for the perfect ceasar.  In my book, a perfect caesar follows the traditional recipe to the letter (although a bit of creativity is allowed, if it's GOOD creativity), and all the ingredients must be fresh (which goes without saying).

Pasquale's caesar fails in two important respects:  they don't follow the traditional recipe (not even a hint of anchovy, and they add some weird herb mix instead), and they use prefab croutons straight out of a box (I know this beyond any doubt because I've been served them at least half the time that I've ordered caesar at a restaurant).  Whoever wrote that the croutons are "fresh" is a FOOL (your 'Elite' status be damned)!  The dressing certainly was strong tasting, and there was plenty of it (if not too much).  Curiously, I found a lonely little garbonzo bean at the bottom of my salad--which has to make you wonder exactly how these salads are prepared.

Still, up to this point I was feeling generous and willing to consider...3 stars.  But then came the meatball sub.  Where to begin dissecting this travesty?  With the worst part, of course:  the sauce.  In my book, the absolute worst insult to a tomato sauce is to call it BLAND.  And that is EXACTLY how to describe this sauce:  BLAND.  No taste of herbs, garlic, or even tomato!  It basically was like red water.  The sandwich was served with french fries, and I'll eat my shorts if they weren't Ore-Ida right out of the freezer.  In all honesty, the Heinz Tomato Ketchup that came with the fries was MUCH tastier than Pasquale's tomato sauce.  Think about that for a minute.

The sandwich was prepared with the same bread that came with my salad (hard sourdough), only toasted.  Barely discernable within each cavernous half were two modest-sized meatballs, some melted mozarella, and maybe a little parmesean cheese.  Despite a relatively generous slatheringing of sauce, the sandwich was still BLAND.  After struggling through the first half, I split open the other half and just ate the meatballs.  How were the meatballs?  In a word, BLAND.

C'mon, Yelpers, is THIS the best SF has to offer?  NO WAY!  I hereby challenge any and all Yelpers to come up with the best--no, good--wait, shoot, at this point I'll take halfway decent--place to get pizza and caesar.  The glove is hereby thrown down!
author: John D.

description:
They serve more than just pizza here. In fact, I have YET to have pizza at Pasquale's! Instead I've been getting the entrees like their lasanga, the chicken parmagiana, and I'm pretty sure I've had a fettucine or two with seafood. Prices are good and I always have leftovers---hecka lots of food.

So if you're in the Inner Sunset definitely check it out. They also seem to have a lot of seating, maybe good for groups?

Times visited: 10+
author: Amy L.

description: Four of us came here for dinner and spent $60 (XL pie, 2x pastas, salad, and a beer). Kinda pricy but worth it for me. Friendly servers and clean old school interior. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Harry Y.

description: This place is hit or miss. When it's good the pizza is really good. When you guys miss, you miss hard. I mean I've had the worst pizza of my life at this place. More consistency would be nice
author: Tokunbo A.

description: Service was a little spotty, but it was a fairly busy night the last time I was there.  I've been going to this place basically my whole life, and they have never let me down.  Great pizza, and the sauteed vegetables were fantastic.  I grew up in the bay area, and now that I live elsewhere, this is one of a handful of places that I want to revisit whenever I come home for a to see the family.
author: Neil T.

description: My favorite Italian place ever. Good food top to bottom. Very nice people.
author: Samer N.

description: We make a special trip out to Pasquale's. It's a family tradition (4 generations! now). I swear it's something in the water...We love this place!
author: Jen C.

description: Wow, really good pizza and great service!!!! I'm still craving after last night.  Left over pizza I took home didn't make it to the next day.  Can't wait to go back!!
author: Sidney I.

description:
This place always delivers hot and tasty food fast and they open till late at night. Most people commented on the pizza, which is really good in my opinion, but they have really great pasta as well.  

Highly recommended: Penne Siciliano (with Italian sausage, red pepper, onion and garlic), baked lasagne

They have so many things on the menu but I find myself kept going back to ordering penne siciliano.
author: Bird A.

description: Ok, so we thought the place looked interesting and always noticed a decent amount of people eating whenever we passed by and decided to check it out. Ordered one of their meat special pizzas with sausage. When it finally came out, we noticed our pizza was really wet on the bottom. Lifted the pizza, saw a puddle of meat juices on the pan. We looked at each other and was clearly turned off. Asked the server why we are eating soggy pizza and the chef's reply was it's the way it is. Where else in the world will they serve you soggy pizza? We politely told the server we can't go on eating the pizza so he waived our bill. (sigh) we left hungry and disgusted.
author: Johanna P.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here because we were drunk and hungry. On that level, Pasquale's is awesome because it's open late. I also like the way the place looks- old school.

However, the pizza itself wasn't that great. They don't even use shredded mozzarella cheese- they put it on in slices. This results in uneven cheese distribution and makes it hard as hell to tear the pizza apart when you get home.

I haven't lived in town long enough to try all the pizza joints, so it's too early to tell if I'll be coming back here sober. Drunk? Probably.
author: Antony M.

description:
Best Mediterranean pizza ever. My all time favorite pizza used to be the Mediterranean (spinach, tomatoes, onions, pesto and garlic). I haven't been to Pasquale's since becoming a vegan, but this pizza is amazing. I used to buy an extra-large so I could enjoy it all week. They have a lot of options for vegetarians (sandwiches, pizzas, salads, pastas, etc.). 

You can see the pizza kitchen right when you walk in and seating is pretty immediate. 

Pros: Right off the N Judah train. Yummy food. 

Cons: Parking in San Francisco is ridiculously inconvenient, but the N Judah train will drop you off close by.
author: Andy C.

description: Pasquales is one of those places where my family and I go every once in a while. A great place for group dining. Also, kind of random, but my favorite caesar salad is from here. I don't know why but I just enjoy theirs the most. Their pizzas and pastas are also pretty good and the portions are great for the price; I always seem to have next day's lunch from dinner here.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Start off with the good. The pizza crust is delicious. You will not find any better; equal maybe, but no better.

Decor is a bit faded, not really vintage, just a bit dated. But at least the place is rarely noisy, even when full. A big plus.

What kills it is salt. The pizza is not just a bit a salty; it's more like the toppings have been carved from a salt rock, then painted to resemble chicken, veggies, pepperoni, cheese and sauce. Seriously, the best part of the pizza is the outside crust.

Lots of potential for a good eating here, just stay away from the solid-salt pizza.
author: Carlo M.

description:
From my perspective, Pasquale's is relatively unfortunate.  They have pretty good pizza.  I'd even venture to say it is above average for the city.  Nonetheless, the interior decor is pretty plain and uninspired.  Accordingly, I'd much rather go to Villa Romana for pizza, or grab a slice and a super cheap beer from Milano's around the corner.  

Truthfully, the pizza at both Villa Romana and Milano's is even better than the above average pizza here.  Accordingly, I can't really ever imagine a good reason to go to Pasquales.  If Pasquale's and I were both in "almost" any other neighborhood in this city - I'd have absolutely no problem making this one of my regular places for pizza.  

The same is definitely true for the pasta here.  Good - but not great, and with Villa Romana just a block over - Pasquale's always loses out.
author: Matthew H.

description: Pesto Pasta was delish. Pizza was soggy like other reviews said. Service was OK.
author: Cindy S.

description:
Very goooood pizza! Nice and cheesy and greasy. Just the way its meant to be! Nice ambiance, nice waitresses. No complaints. Deelish. 

My only reservation is the price, i think it was somewhere around $21 for a large, not like you could find a large for any cheaper anywhere else in SF... im just cheap. 

Anyway, the service was great. We ordered a carafe of wine and the waitress apologized that it was warm and kept it in the fridge for us between glasses. 

Very large large too, 10 big slices. Oh and don't be afraid to take some home, you know how some leftover pizza tastes like rubber, not the case with this stuff. Warmed up next day tastes just as good as in the restaurant.  

If you are a pizza connoisseur like me, this place comes highly recommended.
author: Curtis J.

description:
I have given you guys at least 15 chances over a few years. Tonight I have reached the end. I am done. You failed one last time. I am breaking up with you.

Bad service, mediocre pizza and cold fried calamari (really?? I don't live that far), wrong order ("manager" says "free pizza now or 15% off your next order, even though that doesn't make sense" (yes, he said that)) - this time: you DROPPED the pizza, everything slid to one side, you picked it up anyway and delivered it.

Wake up Stoners. Or hey - maybe that's your market. Good luck. Or hey - you have a market, it being SF. Kudos. 

Bye.

PS: I ALWAYS tipped very generously. I worked in the food industry for years, but I strived for way better. It's PEOPLE'S FOOD.

PPS: HAHA! I love it. That was actually your 420th review!
author: Steph K.

description:
Amazing  chicken parmesan sandwich! The bread is fresh and so good, the chicken isn't greasy and they use just the right amount of cheese and sauce. Heavenly. 

I believe its about $9 bucks with tax.
author: Jax C.

description: I love this place! My family has been eating here as far back as I can remember, so I guess this restaurant has a bit of sentimental value to me. Regardless, the pizza is great. My family and I always order the seafood pizza.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Pasquale's Pizza hit the spot! We had a pesto pizza and charbroiled cheese steak sandwich. The pizza had a good crust and was not greasy, probably because it had just the right amount of pesto sauce and cheese on it. The steak sandwich came on a great toasted sourdough roll and was seasoned well. 

Our server was really sweet throughout dinner and ran outside after me when she saw that I left my cell phone behind on the table.
author: K. D.

description:
When I first got back from Japan. I was craving pizza in a bad way. So I came here. Is there anymore to be said? 

FYI don't come here on Valentines day. The service can be sadly bad. The two waitresses have been here forever and they are really nice, but yeah they can't seem to hire anymore waitresses so it's chaos when it's crowded. 

The mushroom, sausage, and pepperoni combo is the star of the show. I just come here for the pizza. All the other items are pretty mediocre, but I love the pizza and Irving is a great area.
author: Christina Y.

description: I've been coming here for a few years and I think it's great.  I used to dine in after visiting the nearby bars but now I mainly take out.  Thier pizza is fabulous.  You can't walk down Irving without seeing hoards of people carrying Pasuale's boxes. The slices of cheese they use vs. the usual shredded make the texture so rich and flavorful.  Generous with toppings and in terms of affordability it's like ten stars.  Great place!
author: Sin F.

description: Very good pizza at reasonable price.  The waiter was kind of grouchy however.
author: Matt R.

description:
I was not impressed with the decor of the place. Everything is just old. 

I ordered the chicken marinara sandwich. It was dry, and I was not impressed with what they had. Big portion if you're hungry. And it was cheap, but I guess you pay for what you get.
author: Natalie B.

description: This review is not for the restaurant decor. The service was prompt. This review is for the delicious food. My college friends and I would come here for the combination pizza, delicious. Before I came to Pasquales, I had never eaten veal scallopini or veal cacciatore, or linguine with clams and red sauce. I love their linguine.
author: Wilson K.

description:
Summary: Very good eat-in; mixed results take-out/delivery

Was tempted to do two different reviews - four stars for dining in and two stars for take-out...here's what I've found.

Eating at Pasquale's is consistently excellent! The service (with few exceptions) is friendly and good - usually "appropriately" timed (not too fast/not too slow) although it can get a bit slow when crowded.  Food quality is excellent: Pizza is very good (sausage especially yummy), Lasagna is very good, the "Charbroiled Misto" (combo of grilled meats over mushrooms w/veggies or fries) is super-yummy.  The Penne Alla Sicillano is my fave: LOTS of garlic, sausage, fresh tomatoes, peppers, and onions...if you dig those flavors than ya gotta try this one!  Sandwiches are also good (and a good deal price-wise) and come with a decent side salad.   Easily 4 stars here.

Unfortunately, take-out/delivery is another story.  Folks taking the orders on the phone are rude (e.g., "Pasquales, please hold" click!...this happens too often).  They rush thru the order, and (for delivery) don't ask if you want to pay cash or charge and the delivery folks (who are nice) aren't too happy when you hand 'em the plastic and they're expecting greenbacks.  Food quality seems to suffer as well, especially the pizza which never seems quite as good as eat-in.  When picking up orders, they often come off as "we're doing you a favor handing you your food" which bugs me. Possible this has gotten better as I haven't done take-out/delivery in several months, but that was my experiences for about the last 5 years.

Will give props for being one of the few eateries in the area that's open 'till midnight weekdays.

So - strong recommendation to go in for a meal, and mixed feelings for take-out.
author: Steve E.

description:
The pizza here is alright. I much prefer another joint's pie... because I'm biased. 

BUT what I do love here is their pasta with chicken and mushrooms!! I don't know the exact name of it as I haven't been here in a while.. but the pasta dish is mushroom-y, buttery, hearty but not heavy. Will have to go back and get the name of that dish!! and of course, eat it again!
author: Christine C.

description:
What do you expect? It's a pizza place with the word Pizza in the name -- thin or thick, the pasta. It's not fine dining, but it's still all good. 

I used to live in this neighborhood (which I'm convinced is the most comfortable neighborhood in San Francisco, what but do I know?), and ate here ALL THE TIME. It was a bit pricy for what you got (but then again, what isn't pricey in San Francisco), butI loved their pasta -- nothing to pretentious, just mushrooms and sauce. 

Definitely the best place in the neighborhood.
author: Patrick N.

description:
I guess maybe I am writing from a sort of slap-happy perspective on this joint. Bethany and I came here after skinny-dipping (in February, in the ocean, at night) and we toasted before every single sip of Peroni. So the place immediately holds special memories for me.

I appreciated that it was open late; we were feeling peckish after having burned mementos of our tormented lives in a bonfire on Ocean Beach. I had baked manicotti, which is almost never on any menu anywhere that I go. I have to admit, it was not that great: bland, kind of rubbery. Bethany reluctantly agreed that her pasta plate was fairly flavorless.

But the waitress was super nice, and told us a very detailed story about having met Rob Lowe the night before. And the manager, whom it seems everyone else hates on, was really nice to us. And we both came away full and smiling.
author: Olivia P.

description:
pizza's good.  Caesar Salad is AWESOME (just ask to have the dressing on the side, coz they WILL drench yer lettuce, otherwise)...croutons are fresh, not hard.

they don't, however, sell pizza by the slice... aww.
author: Grace M.

description:
YUCK. They're lucky they stay open later than other places on Irving, that's about all they have going for them.

We ordered a large pepperoni pizza to go. Took about a 15 mins. Since we had minimal contact with the employees, there was little time for them to be douchebags so not dinging them on that. But reading from the other reviews, they sound like jerks if you dine in.

Now to the pizza...It's pretty hard to fuck up a standard pepperoni pizza. Sauce, cheese, and meat. But they did the unthinkable, they fucked it up. Half the pizza was SMOTHERED in thick, goopy cheese, while the other half laid there naked with just sauce and pepperoni. WTF. I mean, c'mon, when the sauce isn't great and the cheese is flavorless, you gotta at least learn how to put everything on evenly so the slices are consistently bad. Geez. The pepperoni itself was delicious, haha. 

Anyways, we were hungry and Naan and Curry was closed. We opted for this as the next best thing in a pinch. If you find yourself wandering Irving for something to eat FAST, this is the place to go. But really, I don't recommend it.
author: Jen P.

description:
Bland pizza, terrible customer service.  I mean it's not BAD, it just doesn't taste like anything.

I really don't know how they are still in business.
author: Dong T.

description:
I heard this place had excellent pizza so we had to stop in and order one.  I thought it was strange that most people weren't ordering pizza but instead were ordering their pastas.  I suppose that's not so surprising now that I'm reading other yelpers' reviews.  (i.e when drunk, order pizza.  when sober, pasta is better)
